sections.title: 3D & Digital Dentistry in Shoreham-by-Sea
sections.body:
3D and digital dentistry refers to the way we plan, design, and carry out dental treatment using detailed digital scans rather than relying only on traditional impressions and estimates.

For patients, this means we can see your teeth, bite, and jaw in far greater detail before treatment starts. Digital scans allow us to plan carefully, explain options clearly, and reduce guesswork at every stage.

This technology supports safer planning, clearer communication, and more predictable outcomes. It does not replace clinical judgement or experience — it supports it.

sections.title: Scan → Design → Print/Mill → Fit
sections.body:
Instead of taking physical moulds, we use digital scanners and imaging to build a precise three-dimensional picture of your teeth and mouth.

These scans are used to plan treatments such as crowns, implants, aligners, or complex restorations. Because the information is visual, we can show you what we see and talk through options in a way that is easier to understand.

Digital planning helps us check spacing, bite relationships, and fit before treatment begins, rather than discovering issues part-way through.

sections.title: Patients who want predictable, visual planning
items: From a patient point of view, digital dentistry is mainly about clarity and confidence.

You are able to see proposed treatment plans, understand why a particular approach is recommended, and ask informed questions before decisions are made. Planning happens in advance, which often reduces adjustments, remakes, or surprises later on.
For many treatments, digital workflows also allow for fewer appointments and more accurate fitting restorations, although this depends on the type of care involved.

sections.title: Clear checkpoints from scan to maintenance
items: We use 3D and digital planning across a wide range of treatments, including crowns and bridges, dental implants, orthodontic aligners, and more complex restorative work.
Not every treatment requires digital planning, and it is not used automatically. We recommend it when it adds clarity, accuracy, or safety to your care.
Your dentist will explain whether digital planning is appropriate for your situation and why.
sections.strapline: Timelines vary by case complexity; we share ranges and review points upfront.

sections.title: Precision outputs, clinician-reviewed
sections.body:
Digital imaging allows us to assess structures that are difficult to judge by eye alone, such as tooth position below the gum or bone levels around teeth.

When X-ray-based scans are used, they are prescribed carefully and only when clinically justified. We follow UK radiation guidelines and always balance benefit against exposure.

Digital tools support careful planning, but they do not replace clinical checks, consent discussions, or hands-on assessment.

sections.title: Long-term fit backed by maintenance
items: Printed restorations include guidance on wear limits and review intervals
Occlusion and bite are rechecked after settling to reduce adjustments
Material choices explained, including when ceramics provide more durability
Clear cleaning instructions to protect surfaces and soft tissue
Implant-related prints come with hygiene and torque check plans

faqs.question: When do you recommend porcelain instead of printing?
faqs.answer: We recommend porcelain for cases needing maximum longevity, high gloss, or colour stability. Printed options are useful for provisional stages or conservative veneers when appropriate.

faqs.question: How fast can printed dentures or guards be ready?
faqs.answer: Digital scanning and in-house production shorten turnaround times; we share a range after your assessment and schedule fit appointments accordingly.

faqs.question: Do printed implant restorations need different maintenance?
faqs.answer: We pair them with occlusion checks, hygiene plans, and torque reviews. You’ll know the follow-up cadence before treatment begins.

faqs.question: Can designs be adjusted after I see the preview?
faqs.answer: Yes. We review shape, bite, and shade options with you, then adjust the plan before production.

faqs.question: Does digital dentistry replace traditional techniques?
faqs.answer: Digital tools support planning and accuracy, but traditional clinical skills remain essential. Many treatments combine both approaches depending on what is most appropriate for the patient.
